title: Not all scientific studies are created equal - David H. Schwartz

multiple-choice.question: What type of study is considered the scientific gold standard for determining the effects of a substance on humans?
What is the primary purpose of randomizing subjects in a clinical trial?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that the study is blinded

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the number of participants needed

options.label: C
options.text: To ensure that the only difference between groups is the factor being studied

options.label: D
options.text: To increase the duration of the study

multiple-choice.question: Why might a randomized clinical trial (RCT) not be possible in some cases?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it would require too many volunteers

options.label: B
options.text: Because it would be too expensive

options.label: C
options.text: Because it's not practical or would require too many volunteers

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's not necessary for all studies

multiple-choice.question: What type of study is used when a randomized clinical trial (RCT) is not possible?
What is the primary limitation of epidemiological studies?

options.label: C
options.text: They cannot establish causal relationships between substances and their effects on health

options.label: D
options.text: They are not useful for studying health effects

multiple-choice.question: What are confounding variables in an epidemiological study?

options.label: A
options.text: Factors that are intentionally introduced by the researcher

options.label: B
options.text: Factors that can affect results, in addition to the factor being studied

options.label: C
options.text: Factors that are irrelevant to the study

options.label: D
options.text: Factors that are only present in the control group

multiple-choice.question: Why can't a single epidemiological study demonstrate a cause-and-effect relationship?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's not a randomized clinical trial (RCT)

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's not a well-conducted study

options.label: C
options.text: Because it examines differences between preexisting groups, rather than deliberately inducing changes within the same individuals

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's not a large enough study

multiple-choice.question: What is required by the US Food and Drug Administration before a new drug can be marketed?

options.label: A
options.text: At least one randomized clinical trial (RCT)

options.label: B
options.text: At least two randomized clinical trials (RCTs)

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for a group of people who are already exposed to a substance or factor being studied in an epidemiological study?
What should you do when you see a headline about a new miracle cure or the terrible danger posed by an everyday substance?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediately believe the headline and take action

options.label: B
options.text: Ignore the headline and do nothing

options.label: C
options.text: Try to learn more about the original study and its limitations

options.label: D
options.text: Share the headline with others without verifying the information

title: Making sense of a visible quantum object - Aaron O'Connell

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, which hemisphere of the brain is associated with logic?
What is the speaker's profession?
According to the speaker, how do experimental quantum physicists develop intuition?

options.label: A
options.text: By reading books and attending lectures

options.label: B
options.text: By playing with and experimenting on objects

options.label: D
options.text: By thinking deeply about complex concepts

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the theory that describes the behavior of tiny particles?
What is the speaker's goal in their research?

options.label: A
options.text: To prove that quantum mechanics only applies to small particles

options.label: B
options.text: To show that everyday objects can also exhibit quantum behavior

options.label: C
options.text: To develop a new theory that replaces quantum mechanics

options.label: D
options.text: To study the behavior of particles in different environments

multiple-choice.question: What is the object that the speaker created to demonstrate quantum behavior in everyday objects?

options.label: B
options.text: A piece of metal shaped like a diving board

multiple-choice.question: What conditions are necessary for the piece of metal to exhibit quantum behavior?

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of light, wind, and heat

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the speaker's experiment on the piece of metal?

options.label: A
options.text: It only vibrates in one direction

options.label: B
options.text: It vibrates and does not vibrate at the same time

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the implication of the experiment's result?

options.label: A
options.text: That quantum mechanics only applies to small particles

options.label: B
options.text: That everyday objects can exhibit quantum behavior

options.label: C
options.text: That consciousness is not affected by quantum mechanics

options.label: D
options.text: That the laws of physics are absolute

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's conclusion about the nature of reality?

options.label: A
options.text: That everything is separate and distinct

options.label: B
options.text: That everything is interconnected and defines who we are

options.label: C
options.text: That quantum mechanics is only a theoretical framework

options.label: D
options.text: That consciousness is the fundamental aspect of reality

multiple-choice.question: What is the foundation of Classical Ballet based on?
What was the primary purpose of early dance?

options.label: B
options.text: To convey emotion on stage without words and share a story with the body

multiple-choice.question: What happens when a ballet dancer is not portraying a specific character?

options.label: A
options.text: They have less freedom to express themselves

options.label: B
options.text: They have more freedom to express themselves

options.label: C
options.text: They are required to follow strict choreography

options.label: D
options.text: They are not allowed to improvise

multiple-choice.question: Which ballet caused a riot when it premiered in the early 20th century?
According to the speaker, what is fascinating about the art of ballet?

options.label: A
options.text: Its ability to tell classic stories

options.label: B
options.text: Its ability to evoke emotions in the audience

options.label: C
options.text: That there is still so much more to learn and discover

options.label: D
options.text: Its strict adherence to traditional techniques

multiple-choice.question: How do newer works of ballet often affect the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: They are always easy to watch and understand

options.label: B
options.text: They challenge the audience and can be confrontational

options.label: C
options.text: They are always funny and entertaining

options.label: D
options.text: They are always beautiful and aesthetically pleasing

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's goal when performing ballet?

options.label: C
options.text: To make the audience think and connect with the performance

multiple-choice.question: Why might an audience member laugh during a ballet performance?

options.label: C
options.text: Because the performance is uncomfortable and they don't know how to react

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the most interesting aspect of ballet?

options.label: C
options.text: Having the freedom to express oneself

multiple-choice.question: How long has ballet been evolving as an art form?

options.label: D
options.text: It has not evolved at all

multiple-choice.question: In 479 BC, what natural phenomenon likely saved the Greek city of Potidaea from a Persian invasion?
What is the primary source of energy for normal ocean waves?
What is the most common cause of tsunamis?
How fast can a tsunami move through the ocean?
What happens to a tsunami when it reaches shallow water?

options.label: C
options.text: Wave shoaling occurs, causing the wave's speed to slow down and its height to rise

multiple-choice.question: What is the meaning of the word "tsunami" in Japanese?
What can be a misleadingly dangerous sign of an approaching tsunami?

options.label: B
options.text: A sudden increase in water temperature

options.label: C
options.text: The water withdrawing farther than normal from the shore

multiple-choice.question: How many people were killed in the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami?
What is a current focus of scientists and policy makers in protecting against tsunamis?

options.label: A
options.text: Building sea walls and flood gates

options.label: B
options.text: Establishing global communication networks for early detection and alerts

options.label: C
options.text: Creating channels to divert the water

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Japan's Fukushima Power Plant in 2011?

options.label: A
options.text: It was destroyed by an earthquake

options.label: B
options.text: It was damaged by a flood

options.label: C
options.text: A tsunami surpassed the flood wall, causing a nuclear disaster

options.label: D
options.text: It was hit by a hurricane

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the primary uses of vanadium?
Which group of elements does vanadium belong to?
What is unique about the chemistry of vanadium?

options.label: C
options.text: It has really quite interesting chemistry

options.label: D
options.text: It is rarely found in nature

multiple-choice.question: Where can vanadium be found naturally?
What is the name of the material that is vanadium-rich?
What is the approximate diameter of the vanadium wire shown?
How long is the vanadium wire on the reel?
What happened to the vanadium hexacarbonyl when it was exposed to air?

options.label: C
options.text: It burst into flames and disappeared

multiple-choice.question: Why did the vanadium hexacarbonyl come in a sealed glass vessel?
What happened to the sample of vanadium hexacarbonyl when Paul poured it out?

options.label: A
options.text: It reacted slowly with the air

options.label: C
options.text: It burst into flames and disappeared

multiple-choice.question: What is the color of iodine when dissolved in water?
What is the primary function of the thyroid gland in the human body?

options.label: C
options.text: To control development of various bodily functions

multiple-choice.question: Why is iodine added to table salt in many countries?

options.label: C
options.text: To provide essential iodine for the thyroid gland

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the illness caused by iodine deficiency, characterized by a swelling of the thyroid gland?
What is the purpose of grinding iodine into a fine powder before reacting it with aluminum?
What is the role of water in the reaction between iodine and aluminum?

options.label: B
options.text: To act as a solvent and activate the iodine

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the compound formed in the reaction between iodine and aluminum?
What is a common use of iodine due to its antiseptic properties?
What is the term used to describe the process of iodine changing directly from a solid to a gas?
What is the result of the exothermic reaction between iodine and aluminum?

options.label: A
options.text: The formation of a new crystalline material

options.label: B
options.text: The release of a toxic gas

Why is the speaker cautious about touching the tellurium sample?

options.text: If ingested, it can make a person's sweat smell bad

options.label: A
